imports.value: RowIndex, ColumnIterable, RowIterable, NonzeroIterable, IndexableMatrix, ElementwiseArrayOps
SparseColumnArray, SparseRowArray, RowIterable, NonzeroIterable, ColumnIterable, Array, RowIndex, SparseArrayView, IndexableMatrix, ElementwiseArrayOps

defs.docs: A machine learning crate for Rust.

attributes.value: / A machine learning crate for Rust.
/ This crate is mostly an excuse for me to learn Rust. Nevertheless, it contains reasonably effective
/ implementations of a number of common machine learing algorithms.
/ At the moment, `rustlearn` uses its own basic dense and sparse array types, but I will be happy
/ to use something more robust once a clear winner in that space emerges.
/ - [decision trees](trees/decision_tree/index.html) using the CART algorithm, and
/ All the models support fitting and prediction on both dense and sparse data, and the implementations
/ should be roughly competitive with Python `sklearn` implementations, both in accuracy and performance.
/ Model serialization is supported via `rustc_serialize`. This will probably change to `serde` once
/ - import the prelude for alll the linear algebra primitives and common traits:
/ - import individual models and utilities from submodules:
/ // Optionally serialize and deserialize the model

attributes.value: / An array of ones or zeros:
/ let sum = array.data().iter().fold(0.0, |sum, val| sum + val);
/ On both `f32` and other `Array`s, with both immutable and in-place variants.

defs.name: sparse
defs.docs: Sparse matrices.

attributes.value: / Two main sparse matrices are implemented: `SparseRowArray` and `SparseColumnArray`.
/ Both support efficient incremental construction as well as efficient iteration over
/ nonzero entries. Data is stored as indices and data vectors, in a row-wise or column-wise fashion.
/ `SparseRowArray` allows efficient iteration over rows, and `SparseColumnArray` allows efficient
/         println!("Entry at ({}, {}) is {}", row_idx, column_idx, value);

defs.name: new
defs.value: pub fn new(usize, usize, f32) -> ShuffleSplit
defs.docs: Create a new instance of the shuffle split utility.

attributes.value: / Create a new instance of the shuffle split utility.
/ Iterating over it will split the dataset of size `n_samples`
/ into a train set of `(1.0 - test_size) * n_samples` rows
/ and a test set of `test_size * n_samples` rows, `n_iter` times.

defs.name: random_forest
defs.docs: Random forests.

attributes.value: / Fits a forest of decision trees using bootstrap samples of
/ training data. The predictions of individual trees are averaged
/ to arrive at the final prediction. This counters the tendency
/ of individual trees to overfit and provides better out-of-sample
/ predictions. In general, the more trees fit, the higher the accuracy.

defs.docs: A two-class logistic regression classifier implemented using stochastic gradient descent.

attributes.value: / A two-class logistic regression classifier implemented using stochastic gradient descent.
/ This model implements a two-class logistic regression classifier, using stochastic
/ gradient descent with an adaptive per-parameter learning rate (Adagrad). The model
/ can be regularized using L2 and L1 regularization, and supports fitting on both
/ Repeated calls to the `fit` function are equivalent to running
/ Fitting the model on the iris dataset is straightforward:

defs.docs: Set the initial learning rate.

attributes.value: / During fitting, the learning rate decreases more for parameters which have
/ have received larger gradient updates. This maintains more stable estimates
/ for common features while allowing fast learning for rare features.

defs.name: trees

defs.name: decision_tree
defs.docs: A two-class decision tree classifer.

attributes.value: / This model implements the CART (Classification and Regression Trees)
/ algorithm for both dense and sparse data. The tree is split by
/ randomly sampling `max_features` candidate features, then choosing
/ the best split amongst those features using reduction in Gini impurity.
/ Both binary and numeric features are supported; categorical features
/ without a clear ordering should be one-hot encoded for best results.
/ Fitting the model on the iris dataset is straightforward:
